HEA.fit package¶

Package in order to:

  • Perform fits and save the result: HEA.fit.fit

  • Manage the parameters of the fit: HEA.fit.params

  • Perform fits: HEA.fit.fit

  • Get characteristics of zFit PDFs: HEA.fit.PDF

HEA.fit.PDF module¶

  • Get the number of d.o.f. of a model

  • Get the \(\chi^2\) of a model

  • Get the mean/std of an array

HEA.fit.PDF.get_chi2(fit_counts, counts)[source]¶

Get the \(\chi^2\) of a fit

Parameters

  • fit_counts (np.array or list) – fitted number of counts

  • counts (np.array or list) – number of counts in the histogram of the fitted data

Returns

returns – \(\chi^2\) of the fit

Return type

float

HEA.fit.PDF.get_mean(pull)[source]¶

Get the mean of an array, excluding non-valid values.

Parameters

pull (numpy.array) – Array

Returns

mean_pull – mean of the array

Return type

float

HEA.fit.PDF.get_n_dof_model(model)[source]¶

Get the number of d.o.f. of a zfit model. A d.o.f. corresponds to a floated parameter in the model.

Parameters

model (zfit.pdf.BasePDF) – Model (PDF)

Returns

n_dof – number of d.o.f. in the model

Return type

int

HEA.fit.PDF.get_n_dof_params_recurs(params, params_seen=[], n_dof_previous=0)[source]¶

Recursive function to get the number of d.o.f. of a parameter

Parameters

  • params (zfit.pdf.Parameter or zfit.pdf.ComposedParameter) – Parameter

  • params_seen (list(str)) – list of the names of the parameters that have been seen so far

  • n_dof_previous (int) – number of d.o.f. counted so far

Returns

  • n_dof (int) – number of d.o.f. contained in the list of parameters that aren’t in the list of parameters already seen, to which is added the number of d.o.f. already seen previously.

  • params_seen (list(str)) – list of the names of the parameters that have been seen so far

HEA.fit.PDF.get_reduced_chi2(fit_counts, counts, n_dof)[source]¶

Get the reduced \(\chi^2\) of a fit

Parameters

  • fit_counts (np.array or list) – fitted number of counts

  • counts (np.array or list) – number of counts in the histogram of the fitted data

  • n_dof (int) – number of d.o.f. in the model

Returns

returns – reduced \(\chi^2\) of the fit

Return type

float

HEA.fit.PDF.get_std(pull)[source]¶

Get the standard deviation of an array, excluding non-valid values.

Parameters

pull (numpy.array) – Array

Returns

mean_pull – Standard deviation of the array

Return type

float

HEA.fit.fit module¶

  • Define some PDFs

  • Define the parameters from a dictionnary of training variables

  • Perform a fit (using zfit)

  • Check if the fit has an error (if it did not converge, has not a positive-definite hesse, …)

HEA.fit.fit.check_fit(result)[source]¶

Check if the fit has gone well. If a check has gone wrong, point it out.

Parameters

result (zfit.minimize.FitResult) – result of the minimisation of the likelihood

Returns

False if something has gone wrong in the fit. True if the fit has gone smoothly.

Return type

Bool

HEA.fit.fit.crystall_ball_or_gaussian(mu, sigma, obs, alpha=None, n=None)[source]¶

return a Crystall Ball (CB) or gaussian PDF

  • Gaussian if alpha or n is None

  • CB if none of them are None

Parameters

  • mu (zfit.Parameter) – mean

  • sigma (zfit.Parameter) – standard deviation

  • obs (zfit.Space) – Space

  • alpha (zfit.Parameter) – \(\alpha\) parameter of the tail

  • n (zfit.Parameter) – \(n\) parameter of the tail

Returns

PDF

Return type

zfit.PDF.Gauss or zfit.PDF.CrystallBall

HEA.fit.fit.define_zparams(initial_values, cut_BDT=None, num=None)[source]¶

Define zparams from the dictionnary initial_values

Parameters

  • initial_values (dict) – {“name_variable”: {“value”:, “low”:, “high”:, “floating”:}}

  • cut_BDT (float) – performed cut on the BDT (BDT > cutBDT)

  • num (integer) – Index of the fit. add ";{num}" at the end of the variable/ the other functions I wrote allow to ignore the ";{num}" in the name of the variable. This is used manely in order to define a parameter several times (when tuning their values to make the fit convergent)

Returns

zparams – Dictionnary of zfit Parameters whose keys are the name of the variables and:

  • if cut_BDT is None, the key is just the name of the variable

  • else, the key is "{name_variable}|BDT{cut_BDT}"

Return type

dict[str, zfit.Parameter]

HEA.fit.fit.launch_fit(model, data, extended=False, verbose=True)[source]¶

Fit the data with the model

Parameters

  • model (zfit.pdf.BasePDF) – Overall PDF for the fit

  • data (zfit.data.Data) – Data that will be fitted to

  • extended (if True) – Define or not an extended loss function

  • verbose (Bool) – print or not the result of the fit

Returns

  • result (zfit.minimize.FitResult) – result of the minimisation of the likelihood

  • param (Dict[ZfitParameter, float]) – Result result.params of the minimisation of the loss function (given by launch_fit())

HEA.fit.fit.save_params(params, name_file, uncertainty=True, dic_add=None, folder_name=None, remove=None)[source]¶

Save the parameters of the fit in {loc['json']}/{name_file}_params.json

Parameters

  • params (dict[zfit.zfitParameter, float]) – Result 'result.params' of the minimisation of the loss function (given by launch_fit())

  • name_file (str) – name of the file that will be saved

  • uncertainty (bool) – if True, save also the uncertainties (variables that contain ‘_err’ in their name)

  • dic_add (dict or None) – other parameters to be saved in the json file

  • folder_name (str) – name of the folder

  • remove (list[str] or str or None) – if not None, string to be removed from the names of the parameters

HEA.fit.fit.sum_crystalball_or_gaussian(muL, muR, sigmaL, sigmaR, frac, obs, alphaL=None, alphaR=None, nL=None, nR=None)[source]¶

Return the sum of 2 crystall ball PDFs with tails in opposite side (left or right) or Gaussian PDFs. If the alpha or n is None, the corresponding distribution (left or right) is a gaussian.

Parameters

  • muL (zfit.Parameter) – mean of the left distribution

  • muR (zfit.Parameter) – mean of the right distribution

  • sigmaL (zfit.Parameter) – standard deviation of the left distribution

  • sigmaR (zfit.Parameter) – standard deviation of the right distribution

  • obs (zfit.Space) – Space

  • alphaL (zfit.Parameter) – \(\alpha_L\) parameter of the left tail of the left distribution

  • alphaR (zfit.Parameter) – \(\alpha_R\) parameter of the left tail of the right distribution

  • nL (zfit.Parameter) – \(n_L\) parameter of the left tail of the left distribution

  • nL – \(n_R\) parameter of the right tail of the right distribution

Returns

PDF sum of 2 crystall ball or Gaussian PDFs.

Return type

zfit.PDF.SumPDF

HEA.fit.params module¶

  • Retrieve params

  • Print the result of a fit as a latex table

  • Some formatting function of the dictionnary containing the fitted parameters

HEA.fit.params.get_params_without_BDT(df_params, retrieve_err=False)[source]¶

In the keys of the dictionnary, remove the text from | onwards, except ‘_err’

Parameters

  • df_params (dict) –

    It is supposed to contain the result of the fit, saved in the json files. For instance:

    • {'alphaL': value, 'alphaL_err': value ...}

    • {'alphaL|BDT-0.5': value, 'alphaL|BDT-0.5'_err': value ...}

  • retrieve_err (bool) – if True, include the error of the variables in the file, i.e., the variables whose name contains '_err'

Returns

Formatted dictionnary

Return type

dict

Notes

With my notations, for a BDT cut BDT > 0.2, the variables’ names ends with '|BDT0.2'. Then, this function will the a variable named 'variable|BDT0.2' into a variable named 'variable'.

HEA.fit.params.get_params_without_err(params)[source]¶

get the list of variables from the dictionnary of fitted parameters (including errors)

Parameters

params (dict) – fitted parameters {'alphaL': value, 'alphaL_err': value ...}

Returns

list of variables (excluding the error variables, whose name contain the '_err' string.

Return type

list

HEA.fit.params.json_to_latex_table(name_json, path, latex_params, show=True)[source]¶

transform a json file that contains the fitted parameters and uncertainties into a latex table The latex table is stored into a .tex file in {loc['tables']}/{name_json.tex}

Parameters

  • name_json (str) – name of the json file to load also the name of the future .tex file that will be saved

  • path (str) – path of the json file compared to loc['json'], the default folder for json files.

  • latex_params (dict) – alternative name of the parameters (in latex)

  • show (bool) – if True, print the content of the created latex table code

HEA.fit.params.retrieve_params(file_name, folder_name=None)[source]¶

Retrieve the parameters saved in a json file

Parameters

  • file_name (str) – name of the file

  • folder_name (str) – name of folder where the json file is (if None, there is no folder)

  • library (str) – ‘json’ or ‘pickle’

  • byte_read (bool) – Read in byte mode

Returns

dictionnary that contains the parameters stored in the json file in {loc['json']}/{folder_name}/{name_data}_params.json

Return type

Python object or dic

HEA.fit.params.show_latex_table(name, path=None)[source]¶

Print the latex table that contains the result of a fit. It prints the content of the tex file in {loc['table']}/{path}/{name}_params.tex

Parameters

  • name (str) – name of the fit which we want to get the latex table with its result

  • path (str) – path of the .tex file from loc['tables'], where the .tex file is

Notes

the latex table must have been already generated, for instance with json_to_latex_table().
